author: bridge-bot
content: <cryptodavidw> maybe a stupid question, but if I sync with a chain with chain id A, which then forks into two blockchains with another taking chain id B (and the sync committee and other validators agree to run two chains in parallel) how would I know that I'm now syncing with chain id A which is the one I was interested in? Can I get a proof that the state I'm looking it at is the one from chain id A?

author: bridge-bot
content: <cryptodavidw> looking at https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-155.md it seems like the chainID is only a way to domain separate transactions, but it doesn't seem like there's a way to distinguish which chain you're on if they came from the same trusted block root

author: bridge-bot
content: <etan_status> there is a fork digest which you use for verifying the sync committee signature. on such a split, it would also use a new fork digest. thats how you can also separate mainnet from testnet today, they use separate fork digests on consensus signatures
